title: How Are New Products and Services Developed in Businesses?
summary: The article discusses considerations for developing new products, whether for existing customers or new markets. It highlights that launching new products in new markets involves higher risk due to the need to establish company credentials and overcome market entry barriers. Building on existing customer relationships can ease the process of product launches. Greater marketing effort is necessary when entering new markets.
green_innovation: FALSE: The article does not mention any specific innovation aimed at reducing environmental impacts, therefore it does not qualify as green innovation.
business_innovation: TRUE: The article addresses the development of new products, which aligns with the definition of business innovation as it involves launching new offerings for different or existing markets.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not specify any goods or services designed to significantly reduce environmental impacts throughout their life cycle, thus it cannot be considered a green product.
green_process: FALSE: There is no mention of any specific processes that aim to minimize environmental impacts or promote sustainability in the article.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541611 - Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services, 541618 - Other Management Consulting Services, 541310 - Architectural Services, 541320 - Landscape Architectural Services
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not make misleading claims about environmental benefits; it simply discusses market considerations without references to specific environmental impacts.

title: Consumer Products
summary: The article discusses George Washington Carver's contributions as a scientist and educator at Tuskegee University, including his development of new uses for southern agricultural crops and methods for soil improvement for poor farmers.
green_innovation: TRUE - Carver's work in developing uses for crops and teaching soil improvement methods contributes to environmental sustainability by promoting better agricultural practices.
business_innovation: TRUE - Carver's development of new agricultural uses for crops can be considered a business innovation as it introduces improved methods and research into the agricultural sector.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not specifically mention a good or service that meets the definition of a green product.
green_process: TRUE - The methods Carver taught for soil improvement and resource conservation can be categorized as green processes that promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 111 - Crop Production, 115 - Support Activities for Agriculture and Forestry, 541 - Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services, 611 - Educational Services
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not suggest that Carver or his methods are being misrepresented or exaggerated; rather, it highlights his genuine contributions to agricultural improvement.

title: New Product Development and Introduction
summary: The article suggests that testing a new product in the market prior to manufacturing can help minimize costly mistakes. It recommends creating a prototype for customer feedback or discussing the concept with customers to make adjustments. An internal review should be conducted to ensure the project meets business, technical, and financial objectives, and if shortcomings are found, changes should be made or the project stopped before further resources are committed.
green_innovation: FALSE - The article does not describe any specific green innovation or practices aimed at minimizing environmental impact.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article discusses the process of market testing a new product, which is an improvement in business processes related to product development.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not describe any good or service that significantly reduces environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: FALSE - The article discusses a testing process but does not detail a method specifically aimed at minimizing environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541611 - Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services, 541614 - Process, Physical Distribution, and Logistics Consulting Services, 541615 - Product Development Consulting Services, 541618 - Other Management Consulting Services
greenwashing: FALSE - The article provides straightforward advice on product testing and internal reviews without making misleading claims about environmental benefits, thus does not appear to be an example of greenwashing.

title: The best new products this month from Sonos, Fujifilm and more
summary: The article highlights various new product launches including Sonos Ace headphones, JBL Clip 5 speaker, Fujifilm X-T50 camera, and more. It provides details on features, improvements, and uses of these products aimed mainly at enhancing the user experience in tech and fitness. Each product is positioned as an innovation in its field, showcasing advancements over previous models while focusing on functionality and usability.

title: The Pioneer Womanâ€™s 3 new Walmart-exclusive kitchen appliances are under $60 and available to shop now
summary: Ree Drummond has launched a new small appliance collection in a Linen Speckle colorway for Walmart, including a Digital 2-Slice Toaster, a 6 Qt Slow Cooker, and a 6 Qt Pressure Cooker. The products feature various modern conveniences like programmable settings and are designed to fit into a modern kitchen aesthetic. title: New iMac
summary: The article discusses the rumors and developments surrounding a new, larger iMac model, particularly its potential features, sizes, designs, and processors. It emphasizes the speculation about a 30-inch or larger iMac potentially launching in 2025, but confirms that Apple is not currently working on a 27-inch model. Early rumors suggested various upgrades and design changes, highlighting Apple's push towards efficiency and improved display technologies in future models.
